titleStmt.title: A Novel Performance Criterion Approach to Optimum Design of PID Controller Using Cuckoo Search Algorithm for AVR System

affiliation.orgName: Department of Electronics and Communications Engineering

analytic.title: A Novel Performance Criterion Approach to Optimum Design of PID Controller Using Cuckoo Search Algorithm for AVR System

biblStruct.note: Received date: 26 October 2017 Revised date: 7 May 2018 Accepted date: 22 May 2018

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.p: This article presents a novel tuning design of Proportional-Integral-Derivative (PID) controller in the Automatic Voltage Regulator (AVR) system by using Cuckoo Search (CS) algorithm with a new time domain performance criterion. This performance criterion was chosen to minimize the maximum overshoot, rise time, settling time and steady state error of the terminal voltage. In order to compare CS with other evolutionary algorithms, the proposed objective function was used in Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO) and Artificial Bee Colony (ABC) algorithms for PID design of the AVR system. The performance of the proposed CS based PID controller was compared to the PID controllers tuned by the different evolutionary algorithms using various objective functions proposed in the literature. Dynamic response and a frequency response of the proposed CS based PID controller were examined in detail. Moreover, the disturbance rejection and robustness performance of the tuned controller against parametric uncertainties were obtained, separately. Energy consumptions of the proposed PID controller and the PID controllers tuned the PSO and ABC algorithms were analyzed thoroughly. Extensive simulation results demonstrate that the CS based PID controller has better control performance in comparison with other PID controllers tuned by the PSO and ABC algorithms. Furthermore, the proposed objective function remarkably improves the PID tuning optimization technique.

div.head: A C C E P T E D M A N U S C R I P T 1 Introduction
div.p: In power systems, automatic voltage regulator (AVR) is used for sustaining the terminal voltage of a synchronous generator at an acceptable level. The AVR system controls the consistency of the terminal voltage by varying the exciter voltage of the generator [1]. Generally, the stability and transient performance of the regulator is difficult to achieve because of load variation and the high inductance of the generator field windings in power systems. At the present time, the AVR system has received much attention in the industries to maintain the constant terminal voltage in the synchronous generator under all the conditions. Nevertheless, to obtain improved transient and dynamic voltage stability, optimal controller parameters in AVR system are highly desirable. Many recent approaches of optimal gain tuning methods for the controller parameters of the AVR system has been studied. During the past decades, several control structures have been developed significantly. Nevertheless, among these controllers, the PID controller is the most widely used controller in industries since it is easy to design and carry out. Stability, design, applications and performance of the PID controllers have been widely studied in literature [2]. Therefore, the PID controller is still a proper choice for the AVR system.

It has been a crucial problem to set properly gains of the PID controller, especially in many industrial systems that have higher order, time delay and nonlinearities. Therefore, numerous methods have been used for optimal tuning of the PID controller. Tuning methods for the PID parameters can be classified as traditional, artificial intelligence and evolutionary computation methods. Generally, it is difficult to achieve the best performance of the system by using conventional methods such as Ziegler-Nichols. This method cannot provide optimal PID tuning parameters and also usually produce oscillations and a large overshoot. Moreover, the designer has to depend on his experience such that the best performance is obtained [3]. On the other hand, artificial intelligence approaches such as fuzzy logic and neural network have been applied to solve the optimization problem of the PID controller parameters [4][5][6]. But, the training process and convergence time become cumbersome and long in the artificial neural network. As for a fuzzy logic system, in fuzzy membership function generation, the results usually depend on the analysis of data, tuning of a model and skills of the designer [7][8].

In recent years, many intelligent optimization algorithms based evolutionary computation techniques have been proposed to tune the parameters of the PID controller in the AVR system. Such algorithms include Taguchi Combined Genetic Algorithm (TCGA) [1], Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO) [9][10], Many Optimizing Liaisons (MOL) [11],

div.head: A C C E P T E D M A N U S C R I P T
div.p: Artificial Bee Colony (ABC) [12], Chaotic Ant Swarm (CAS) [13], Genetic Algorithm and Bacterial Foraging (GA-BF) [14], Local Unimodal Sampling Optimization (LUS) [15], Teaching Learning Based Optimization (TLBO) [16].

Hasanien [1] proposed a novel TCGA method to design a PID controller in the AVR system. A multi-objective design optimization was introduced to minimize the step response characteristics. Moreover, the effectiveness of the proposed approach was compared to that of the GA and PSO algorithms. Finally, fast design and an efficient performance prediction were performed. Mouayad and Bestoun [9] addressed a novel time domain objective function based on the multi-objective Pareto front solutions for tuning the PID controller parameters with PSO algorithm in the AVR system. It was shown that the suggested performance criterion improves the PID tuning optimization compared to the objective functions commonly used in the literature. Gaing [10] presented an optimal PID controller design using PSO with a time domain performance criterion for the AVR system. Also, the comparison of the results between PSO and GA algorithms has been given. The comparative results showed that the proposed approach has better tuning capability than GA and also, is more efficient and robust in improving the step response of the system. Panda et al. [11] proposed a MOL algorithm for the design and performance analysis of the PID controller for the AVR system. The integral time-weighted absolute error (ITAE), integral absolute error (IAE), integral time-square error (ITSE) and integral square error (ISE) were considered. Also, the effect of these objective functions on the performance of the system in terms of step response characteristics were analyzed. The results showed that the proposed controller for the AVR system outperforms the other similar optimization algorithms recently reported in the literature. Gozde and Taplamacioglu [12] examined comparative performance analysis of ABC algorithm for controlling AVR system. The robustness of the proposed method has been compared to different algorithms such as PSO and differential evolution (DE) in terms of the characteristic analyses. The simulation results demonstrated that the ABC tuned PID controller allows to control the AVR system robustly and optimally. Zhu et al. [13] presented a novel design method for finding out the PID parameters of the AVR system using the CAS. For the purpose of showing the performance of the proposed method, the results of comparison between the CAS-PID and GA-PID controller were given. The effectiveness and feasibility of the PID controller tuned with CAS algorithm were verified with the simulation results. Kim [14] suggested the hybrid system consisting of GA and BF for optimizing the PID controller of the AVR system using a time domain objective function. Also, the hybrid system was compared to GA, PSO, GA-PSO. Finally, the simulation results demonstrated that the proposed system is highly satisfactory. Mohanty et al. [15] proposed an approach for obtaining the optimal PID controller parameters of the AVR system based on the LUS algorithm. Furthermore, various conventional objective functions and modified objective functions concerning peak overshoot and settling time with some appropriate weighting factors were employed to find the optimum controller parameters. The simulation results showed that the proposed method gives better dynamic performance in comparison with the presented optimization algorithms. Chatterjee and Mukherjee [16] presented TLBO algorithm as an optimization technique to find out the optimum values of the PID controller in the AVR system. The results showed that the proposed algorithm is a considerable optimization tool in determining the optimal PID controller parameters of the AVR system. Blondin et al. [17] presented a meta-analysis of the literature on the optimal tuning PID controller parameters solving the AVR problem. As a result, in that paper, the investigation revealed that the proposed tuning method acquires better or equivalent PID solutions in terms of the overall transient response in comparison with other AVR tuning propositions. Also, the simulation results showed that the proposed tuning method exhibits higher computational efficiency compared to previously published methods. Chatterjee et al. [18] explored a comparative performance study of two new classes of PSO for the PID and PSS controlled AVR system. Also, GA was considered for the sake of comparison. Finally, it was revealed that the proposed tuning method provides better transient performance compared to GA while applying to PID controlled AVR system and PSS controlled AVR system. Supol and Wudhichai [19] presented an optimal PID controller design for the AVR system using a new method based on hybrid of PSO and Gravitational Search Algorithm (PSOGSA). In that paper, for showing the effectiveness of the proposed technique, the transient response analysis and bode analysis were conducted. As a result, from the analysis, the proposed PSOGSA algorithm obtains better results in comparison with other tuning methods such as the Ziegler-Nichols, PSO and MOL for the AVR system. Kashki et al. [20] proposed an efficient optimization method based on reinforcement learning automata (RLA) for tuning the PID controller parameters of the AVR system. Also, its performance was compared with PSO and GA. Finally, in that paper, the simulation results indicated the superior efficiency and performance of the proposed method in consideration of other algorithms. Bahgaat and Moustafa Hassan [21] discussed the methods to obtain the best possible tuning parameters of the PID controller for the AVR system. In that work, Modified Adaptive Acceleration Coefficients based PSO (MAAPSO) was proposed as a new method. Also, some modern methods were defined as: PSO, Adaptive Weight PSO, Adaptive Acceleration Coefficients based PSO and Adaptive Acceleration Coefficients based PSO. A comparison between the results of all methods given was done. It was inferred from the simulations that the proposed method can provide higher quality solution with better computation efficiency compared to the other methods. Devaraj and Selvabala [22] presented a combined GA and fuzzy logic approach for optimal tuning of PID controller parameters in AVR system. Moreover, the performance of the proposed algorithm under various operating conditions was analyzed

div.head: A C C E P T E D M
div.p: A N U S C R I P T through computer simulation. As a result, the simulation results demonstrated the suitability of the proposed approach to obtain the optimal parameters of the PID controller during real-time operation of the system.

Generally, in the suggested method, finding of optimum controller parameters is very important to accomplish the acceptable level of robust performance. Considering the recent researches in optimizing the PID controller parameters of the AVR system, a Cuckoo Search (CS) algorithm can be used to design a better PID control of the AVR system. CS is a new metaheuristic optimization algorithm which is inspired by the way of cuckoos' search for nests where they could lay their eggs [23][24]. Yang and Deb [25] proposed this algorithm taking into account the reproduction behavior of cuckoo based on the three rules [26]. In both papers, they demonstrated better efficiency of the CS algorithm in finding a global optimum as well as a higher degree of its success when compared with GA and PSO algorithms.

In the light of researches in literature, most of the reported works have focused on evolutionary optimization algorithms to find the optimal PID controller parameters for the AVR system. In the existing research works, the simulation results have some deficiencies in obtaining the response behavior that is usually specified in terms of time domain parameters. They are used to assess the unit step response. Such parameters are settling time, rise time, maximum overshoot and steady state error. A PID controller, tuned by the reported algorithms above, may remove this disadvantage of the AVR system and improve the unit step response by minimizing these parameters. To this end, numerous objective functions have been proposed in the literatures as a performance criterion [1,[9][10][11]14]. These functions can be classified as numerous weighted time and frequency domain. It is difficult to choose the appropriate objective function and identify the best weight values required for time-domain optimal-tuning PID control or frequency-domain optimal-tuning PID control of the AVR system. The time domain integral error performance criteria are widely used objective functions that are based on calculating the error signal between the reference signal and the system output. These well-known integral performance indices are IAE, ITAE, ISE, ITSE and integral of squared time multiplied by squared error (ISTE). The minimization of IAE and ISE may result in a response with a relatively small overshoot but a long settling time since they weigh all errors uniformly independent of time. On the other hand, the ITAE and ITSE performance criteria can overcome the disadvantage of the IAE and ISE, however these criteria cannot ensure the needed stability boundary [9,27]. In addition to them, a new time domain performance criterion has been defined by Zwe-Lee Gaing in which the unit step timing parameters are used with only one weighting factor [10]. A general objective function in time domain and frequency domain to facilitate the control strategy has been proposed by Zamani et al. [28]. This performance criterion consists of eight terms including two frequency parameters that the significance of each is set by a weight factor. As a result of literature survey, the proposed performance criteria can seek optimal controller design parameters.

In this work, the optimal design of the PID controller is achieved by minimizing the proposed time performance criterion using PSO, ABC and CS algorithms for the AVR system. For obtaining the better control performance, , , and of the step response can be achieved as the minimum values. Therefore, the proposed criterion includes the time domain specifications that are the overshoot, the settling time and the steady state error as well as mean of time weighted absolute error. By using this performance criterion, the optimal PID controller parameters in the AVR system are determined through PSO, ABC and CS algorithms. This proposed method effectively investigates a high-quality solution and improves the transient response of the AVR system.

div.head: Contribution of this study
div.p: In summary, the main contributions of this paper are as follows:

 Propose a new time domain performance criterion based on two or more conflicting objective functions to be minimized simultaneously in the PID controller design for the AVR system using the CS algorithm.  Compare the results obtained by the CS with those obtained by other optimization algorithms recently reported in the literatures.  Examine the robustness of the PID controller tuned with CS under parametric variation of the AVR system.  Investigate the degree of tracking and disturbance rejection of the proposed controller design compared to various PID controllers tuned by modern heuristic optimization algorithms via different objective function proposed in the literature.

The robustness performance of the proposed PID controller is tested by carrying out the simulations under three operating conditions, and also the results are compared with various PID controllers tuned by the algorithms reported in the literature for the AVR system. In case 1, the performance of the proposed controller is measured by considering that the system uncertainties are variations of time constants of each blocks of the AVR system. The variation of system gains is changed from their nominal values in the range of +50% to -50% in steps of 25%. In case 2, the tracking capability of the proposed controller is compared under presence of parametric uncertainties in the generator, exciter and amplifier model parameters. In case 3, by producing a disturbance and showing results graphically, the disturbance rejection capability and signal outputs of the controllers are demonstrated.

div.head: A C C E P T E D M A N U S C R I P T
div.p: The remaining part of this paper is organized as follows. In section 2, the modeling of AVR system is described in detail. The analysis of the AVR system with the PID controller is given in Section 3. An overview of the CS algorithm is presented in Section 4. Section 5 gives mathematical problem formulation for the optimization of PID gains. Section 6 is devoted to simulation results and comparative study. Finally, the conclusions are given.

div.head: AVR System Modeling
div.p: Excitation control of a synchronous generator is one of the most important factors for improving power system stability and quality of electrical power [29]. The major task of the AVR system in a power plant is to maintain the terminal voltage magnitude in the synchronous generator automatically at a desired level which affects the security of the system. Generally, for the AVR there are three important duties, namely better regulation of voltage, stability improvement and decreasing overvoltage on loss of load. Consequently, it is required to design a controller for an AVR system to improve its stability and transient performance.

A simple AVR system comprises four main components including amplifier, exciter, generator and sensor. The transfer function of each component is modeled by a first order system defined by a time constant and a gain. Table 1 gives more details regarding the transfer functions corresponding gain and time constant typical ranges [10].

Table 1. The block models in the AVR system. Figure 1 shows the arrangement of the AVR system components, where , and are the reference voltage, error voltage (the difference between the reference and the sensed terminal voltages) and terminal voltage, respectively.

In order to compare the results in a fair manner, the parameters of AVR system are set as given in Figure 1 as the same as in the research works [1,[9][10][11][12][14][15] reported above. Given model parameter values shown above, the closed loop transfer function is obtained as following equation for the AVR system.

The step response of the system is shown in Figure 2. The transfer function of has one zero at , two real poles at and , and two complex poles at . It can be observed from Figure 2 that the AVR system possesses an underdamped response with (maximum overshoot), (maximum rise time), (maximum settling time) and (maximum steady state error) at which the response has settled to 98% of the steady state value.

div.head: Analysis of the AVR System with PID Controller
div.p: The dynamic response of the AVR system can be improved by using PID controller. The PID controllers are usually preferable because of its simple structure and easy implementation. The PID controller comprises three main control actions in association with the error signal in proportional, integral and derivative ways. The transfer function of the PID controller is given by:

where , and are the proportional, integral and derivative gains, respectively. The block diagram of the AVR system with the PID controller is shown in Figure 3. (3) By substituting the transfer functions of the AVR system components listed in Table 1 with their values and the transfer function of the PID controller given by Equation 2 in Equation 3, the final transfer function of the AVR system controlled by the PID in above equation is obtained as follows
div.formula: (s V ref ) (s V e s 1 . 0 1 10  s 1 1 1  ) (s V t s 01 . 0 1 1  ) (s V s s 4 . 0 1 1  s K s K K d i p   ) (s U A C C E P T E D M A N U S C R I P T
div.p: The basic characteristic of the transient response of the system shown in Figure 1 is closely associated with the location of the closed-loop poles. Consequently, the location of the closed loop poles depends on the values of the loop gains chosen. From this point of view, the gain adjustment of the PID controller may move the closed loop poles to a desired location. For proper design of the PID controller, the design problem then becomes the selection of the appropriate gain values such that the PID controller can compensate the effect of two real poles of the AVR system. As a result, a suitable tuning method of the PID gain parameters must be selected to improve the dynamic response as well as reduce or eliminate the steady state error. In this work, with the new proposed performance criterion, the optimization algorithm employed for designing the PID controller will attempt to tune the controller parameters.

div.head: Cuckoo Search Algorithm
div.p: In 2009, Xin-She Yang and Suash Deb developed a new population-based metaheuristic optimization technique known as cuckoo search algorithm. This algorithm is inspired from the brood parasitic breeding strategy of certain species of cuckoos by laying their eggs in the nests of other host birds [25]. This algorithm imitates the cuckoo's behavior of finding the other bird species' nest for development and care of its young ones.

The Cuckoos never build their own nest and intelligently use other bird species' nest in which the host bird has just laid its eggs. Cuckoo birds imitate the color and pattern of eggs of some of the host species. Thus, they are able to lay eggs which look like the egg(s) of the host bird in their nest. In this way, their chick will be part of and replace one of the eggs of the host bird with their egg within seconds. Once the cuckoo's chick is hatched, his first instinct action is to throw the host eggs out from nest. Hence, it would increase the cuckoo chick's share of food supplied by its host bird, and also gain access to more feeding opportunity by mimicking the call of host chicks [30]. Some host birds identify the cuckoo's egg, and they either throw the foreigner eggs out of their nest or permanently abandon the nest to develop a new one [25,31].

In this optimization algorithm, the main theme is to select the best nest with optimal solutions. Each nest is regarded as a potential candidate. The significant rules that are used for the cuckoo reproduction process in CS algorithm are presented as follows [26]:

1. Each cuckoo lays an egg and drop it in a randomly chosen nest, 2. The best nests have the optimal solution and carry over to the next generation of cuckoos (the next step), 3. The available host nests are restricted in numbers and a host bird can discover the foreign eggs by a probability ( ) between [ ] range.
For generating the new nest for cuckoos, the global random walk is performed by using a law named Lévy flights which is given below:
where indicates the current iterations in which N denotes the predetermined maximum iteration number.

is the step size regarding the scales of the problem of interest. An important parameter of the CS algorithm is the use of which is Lévy flight for both local and global searching. Lévy flight process is basically a random walk which is derived from the Lévy distribution with an infinite variance and infinite mean given in Equation 6 [32]. This process is one of the most powerful features of cuckoo search to produce a new candidate solution or egg providing by a random walk [26].
div.formula: A C C E P T E D M A N U S C R I P T (6)
div.p: where is the iteration number. This equation in the proposed CS algorithm is developed using the exponential law by Mantegna [32]. Mantegna's algorithm yields random numbers with respect to a symmetric Lévy stable distribution. The algorithm is initialized by taking individually solution from the initial population, and then replacing it by a new vector generated using the steps. Here the steps fundamentally constitute a random walk process with a power law steplength distribution with a heavy tail [33].

The basic steps involved in the CS algorithm can be given as the pseudo code shown in Figure 4. In short, initial population is produced using random numbers. The error related to each population is then determined. In each iteration, some quality solutions are stored for further processing and the rest are updated using Lévy flight.

div.head: Proposed Algorithm
div.p: Design of the proposed CS based PID controller is presented in this section. More specifically, the design of an objective function, design of the PID controller using the proposed algorithm and definition of lower and upper bounds of the problem are given in the following subsection, respectively.

div.head: Design of an objective function
div.p: The performance of the AVR system is evaluated based on an objective function including time domain specifications which are overshoot ( ), rise time ( ), settling time ( ) and steady state error ( ). The better control performance can be obtained when , , and of the step response are achieved as the minimum values.

The PID controllers designed for the same AVR system are related to one of the aforementioned tuning algorithms and one objective function proposed in recent literature. The different objective functions used are the [12], [11], ( ⃗ ) [10,16],

respectively. In Equations 7-12, and are the reference voltage and terminal voltage, respectively, and is the simulation time. , and are the various weighting factors and is the control error, and ⃗ [ ] is the vector of PID gains.

From the literature review [9][10][11][12][13][14][15][16], it is found that the researchers used various objective functions in optimal PID design problem for the AVR system. Frequently, these objectives are conflicting with each other, e.g., ITAE and integral of the squared deviation of the controller output (ISDCO). Also, in practice, it is difficult to ensure reliable and robust performance for a system with complex dynamics using one performance criterion. Here, taking into consideration both of transient response and steady state performance, the design problem related to the PID controller for the AVR system is specified by the following objective function. This function includes minimization of mean of time weighted absolute error, overshoot, the settling time and the steady state error.

The importance of each of these elements in the objective functions defined above is given by weighting factors , . Choosing the weighting factors gives flexibility to the users to obtain the best performance. However, the selection of the weighting factors is not easy task, and there are many ways to do it. In this paper, several trials were carried out for the optimization process by using various values of the weighting factors. These values could be determined considering the values used in the recent works given above for the same AVR system. The smallest value of the proposed objective function was obtained for , , , , and the simulation time in Equation 13 was set to 3 s.

div.head: A C C E P T E D M A N U S C R I P T
Design of PID controller using CS algorithm
div.p: In this subsection, the CS algorithm with the proposed objective function is utilized to design the controller parameters , and in order to perform desired response and robust stability of the controlled system. From Equation 4, it is clearly visible that there are three parameters in the controlled AVR system that can be tuned to make an effective controller. The design steps for obtaining the optimal solution are expressed as follows:
Step 1: Initialize a population of host nests . Set the maximum number of iterations as the stopping criteria, and also set the objective function as given in Equation 13.

Step 2: Generate a cuckoo called as arbitrarily using the Lévy flight as presented in Equation 5, and calculate its fitness with respect to the proposed objective function for the parameter tuning problem. Step3: Select a nest among the randomly generated population and compute its objective function value as
Step 4: Compare the values and . If ( ), then the host nest is replaced by the new nest obtained with Lévy flight.
Step 5: A fraction of the worst nests is abandoned and new nests are produced at new locations with Lévy flight.
Step 6: Calculate the objective function values of all new produced nests.
Step 7: Update the best nest of the current iteration.

Step 8: The best nest obtained in the current iteration is replaced by the best nest of the iteration if the objective value of the best nest of the iteration is less than the objective value of the best nest .
Step 9: Repeat steps 2-8 until the stopping criteria. The best nest obtained at the final iteration represents the optimal solution to the parameter tuning problem.

div.head: Evolutionary algorithms considered and constraints of the present work
div.p: A simulation study is performed with other artificial intelligence algorithms like PSO and ABC in order to evaluate the performance of the proposed CS algorithm, and compare with the results obtained by these algorithms for the AVR system. To have a fair comparison of three considered algorithms, the similar computational effort such as the maximum iteration, population size, search dimension and number of runs as given in Table 2 is considered for determining the optimal parameters of PID. The simulation parameters of the CS, PSO and ABC algorithms are listed in Table 2.

div.head: Sampling Time s
div.p: In the present research work, in order to improve the search process of the optimization algorithms given in the table, it is necessary to restrict the dimensions of the search space. In PID controller tuning, defining the lower and the upper bounds of the gains is important for control system stability. These limits can be defined by the following constraints, (14) where the superscripts and are the minimum and maximum values of the gains, respectively. In this study, based on the detailed literature review, it has been found that the optimum values of proportional, integral and derivative gains of the PID are within [0, 1.5], [0, 1], [0, 1] for , and respectively [10][11]15].

div.head: A C C E P T E D M A N U S C R I P T 6 Simulation Results and Discussions
div.p: In this section, closed loop performance of the AVR system controlled by the PID is given. In optimizing the gains of the PID, the PSO, ABC and CS algorithms employ the proposed objective function defined in Equation 13. The performance of the proposed CS based PID controller is compared with the PID controllers tuned by recently published modern heuristic optimization algorithms using various performance criterion. Moreover, transient response, frequency response and robustness analysis are carried out on the proposed PID controller. The derivative action in the PID controller is the most critical term. It should be defined in a suitable way to obtain the accurate dynamic results. The transfer function of the PID controller (a first order filter is added to the derivative term) is given as the following (15) where is the time constant of the first order filter. When the approaches zero, will be equivalent to . For this reason, the time constant is set to 0.001 such that the output signal of PID controller with filtered derivative action is liken to the output signal of .

The proposed methods have been implemented in MATLAB/SIMULINK software and all simulations have been performed on personal computer having Intel Core TM 2 quad processor, 2.50 GHz, and 4 GB RAM. Results of interest are marked in bold in the respective tables.

The results (best, worst, average and standard deviation results and CPU time) of the comparisons between PSO and ABC and CS algorithms using the proposed objective function are given in Table 3 for optimal tuning PID parameters in the AVR system. From the table, it can be obviously seen that the proposed CS algorithm outperforms the other algorithms in a statistically significant way over the tuning problem. On the other hand, the PSO algorithm is of better the execution time needed for solving the optimization problem. The CPU usage values for different algorithms are demonstrated in Figure 5 during the tuning. As shown in the figure and the table, while the CPU time taken by the PSO algorithm for the tuning process has smaller, the CPU usage value is higher compared to others algorithms. As for the CS algorithm, it needs much more CPU time; but, requires less CPU usage for each instance. This observation points out that CS is less complex compared with others. Figure 6 depicts the results of 10 trials when the proposed objective function is used for tuning the controller parameters with PSO, ABC and CS. As observed in Figure 6, for all trials, the range of the PID gains tuned by CS has led to a more consistent situation than that of other algorithms. Similarly, from the design viewpoint, the rise time, the settling time and the overshoot obtained from CS has a variation within a smaller range compared to PSO and ABC.

div.head: A C C E P T E D M A N U S C R I P T
div.p: Terminal voltage step response of the AVR controlled with the different PID controllers based on the PSO, ABC and CS algorithms is shown in Figure 7. Moreover, Table 4 presents the best solutions found by the algorithms and the corresponding time indices based on , , with %5 and . In figure 7, it is clear that the unit step response is almost closer to each other for different algorithms based PID controllers. However, the CS based PID controller has better performance for percent overshoots compared to others. On the other hand, the best performance in terms of settling time and rise time has been given by the ABC based PID controller. As can be seen from Figure 6-7 and Table 3-4, the proposed CS based approach with the given objective function has superior features including a stable convergence characteristic and a significant improvement in CPU usage keeping the control error closer to zero. This algorithm efficaciously seeks a high-quality solution and improves the dynamic response of the AVR system.

div.head: Transient response analysis
div.p: The transient response of the PID controller tuned by CS with the proposed objective function is analyzed by comparing the unit step responses with different optimized PID controllers in the recent literature. The PID controllers were optimized using PSO [9][10], MOL [11], ABC [12], GA-BF [14] and LUS [15] algorithms for the same AVR system.

The terminal voltage step responses of the proposed PID controller and different optimized PID controllers for the AVR system are compared as shown in Figure 8. Each PID controller is related to one of the aforementioned optimization techniques and objective functions (OF). From Figure 8, it may be concluded that the PID controller tuned by CS with the proposed objective function has a better step response behavior in comparison with the other optimized PID controllers for the same AVR system. Also, comparative numerical results of the responses yielded by the optimized PID controllers including controller parameters, time domain and steady state performance indices are reported in Table 5. In comparison to PID-PSO [10], PID-MOL [11], PID-BF-GA [14] and PID-LUS [15] with various objective functions presented in Table 5, it may be found that the proposed CS-PID controller with the considered objective function obtains better results with three performance indices which are , and , and only little worse . Moreover, it is clear from Table 5 that the proposed objective function is comparable to the case of W and OF4. The values from the proposed objective function for PID-CS are smaller as compared to PID-PSO [10] and PID-LUS [15] controllers.

div.head: A C C E P T E D M A N U S C R I P T
div.p: It is observed from the table that the performance indices ( and ) values obtained with ABC-PID [12] and PSO-PID [9] are less than other PID controllers, respectively. However, these controllers have more overshoot and oscillations as shown in Figure 8. On the other hand, the designed PID controller using the CS algorithm shows superior performance over the different optimized PID controllers in terms of the system overshoot and steady state error. As a result, the PID controller tuned with CS has the capability to get the most stable (minimum overshoot) and accurate (minimum response oscillation) terminal voltage step response in comparison with the other PID controllers tuned by the different algorithms.

div.head: Frequency response analysis
div.p: The frequency response of the AVR system with the proposed CS based PID controller is analyzed. The magnitude and phase plot of the AVR system with the proposed PID controller is shown in Figure 9. The system's frequency

div.head: A C C E P T E D M
div.p: A N U S C R I P T response characteristics like peak gain, phase margin, delay margin and bandwidth are given in Table 6 and compared with different optimized PID controllers. It is observed from Table 6 that the CS based PID controller is the most stable system in comparison with different optimized PID controllers. The AVR system with the proposed PID controller exhibits minimum peak gain 0 dB at 0 Hz, maximum phase margin 180°, infinite delay margin (the smallest delay destabilizing the system) and maximum bandwidth (the wider bandwidth, the smaller rise time). It may be remarked that a wide bandwidth allows the system to follow reference signals with high accuracy. It is inferred that the best frequency response characteristic giving an idea of the dynamic response of the AVR system can be obtained with the proposed tuning method.

div.head: Robustness analysis
div.p: The robustness analysis is used to evaluate the ability of the controller in attenuating the effect of the parametric uncertainties in the system. Here, the robustness of the proposed CS based PID controller is tested in presence of uncertainties of the AVR system parameters. Firstly, the uncertainties of the AVR system include variation of time constants ( , , and respectively) within range of ±50% of the nominal value with steps of 25%. show step responses of the CS based PID controlled AVR system with , , and time constant variations according to nominal values, respectively. It can be seen from Figures 10111213, that the deviations of the voltage step response curves from the nominal response for the selected parameters are in a small range. It can be inferred from this, that the PID controller optimized by CS exhibits sufficient robustness in spite of large parametric variations of the system. The robustness analysis results for the proposed PID controller, and the total deviation ranges and maximum deviation percentages of the system are given in Table 7 and8

div.head: A C C E P T E D M A N U S C R I P T
div.p: The average deviations of the maximum overshoot, settling time, rise time and peak time provided in Table 8 are 4.2%, 90.4%, 22.9% and 344.9%, respectively. The ranges of total deviation are within tolerable range and limit. Therefore, the AVR system controlled by the proposed CS based PID controller can still perform robust control performance.

Secondly, the experiments considering all dynamic parameter (the gains and time constants) uncertainties of the AVR system are implemented for testing the robustness of the proposed controller parameters obtained at nominal condition. By this means, it is assumed that the generator, exciter and amplifier model parameters are respectively changed to and , and , and from actual values as specified in Figure 1. The comparison of performance between the proposed CS based PID controller and different optimized PID controllers as well as the corresponding terminal voltage step response of the AVR system is given in Table 9 and shown in Figure 14-16, respectively.

From Table 9, it is observed that a brief overview of the table focuses on the novelty of the CS based PID controller with the proposed objective function. In this table, PID-CS maintains lesser values of the maximum overshoot. As it is observed in terms of variation of system dynamic parameters; in comparison with PID-LUS [15], the maximum overshoot and settling time for the proposed PID-CS are better under the uncertainty of the amplifier and the generator although both of them has almost the same rise time and steady state error. Under the uncertainty of the exciter, the proposed control strategy can provide good dynamic response as compared to PID-PSO [10]. Also, Figure 14-16 exhibit the same observations. It is concluded that the proposed CS based PID controller is more robust and better compared to other optimized PID controllers from the point of all performance indices under the variation of parameters.

div.head: Simulink Implementation
div.p: The realization of the proposed CS based PID controller with first order filter on derivative term and its implementation are tested in SIMULINK ® and compared with PID-PSO [9], PID-PSO [10], PID-MOL [11], PID-ABC [12], PID-BF-GA [14], PID-LUS [15] and PID-TLBO [16] controllers. Figure 17 shows the general Simulink model of the AVR controlled by PID with first order derivative filter as defined in Equation 15. In order to illustrate the ability to quick reaction to the occurrence of unexpected disturbances, the responses of the proposed PID controller and different optimized PID controllers are tested under a given disturbance load signals. Values of the disturbance signals are equal to +10% and -10% of the set point at times 3s and 5s, respectively. Set point response due to step input at t=0s and response when the disturbances occur at t=3s and 5s as well as the controller outputs are depicted in Figure 18 Compared to PID-PSO [10], PID-LUS [15] and PID-TLBO [16] in terms of maximum overshoot, rise time and settling time, the proposed CS-PID controller is quick and has better in disturbance rejection as observed in Figure 18 and Table 10. These comparative results indicate that the proposed method exhibits better time response characteristics as compared to the others. On the other hand, the responses of PID-PSO [9], PID-ABC [12] and PID-BF-GA [14] are faster in comparison with CS-PID controller, however, they have the highest maximum overshoot values as seen from Table 10. In figure 19 and Table 11, the control signal with the proposed CS-PID controller has greater magnitude than PID-MOL [11], PID-LUS [15] and PID-TLBO [16], but the proposed CS-PID controller has a very good load disturbance response in terms of minimum values of all performance indices. As a result, the PID controller tuned by the CS using the proposed objective function outperforms PID controllers tuned with the aforementioned optimization techniques and objective functions in stabilizing the AVR system under this load disturbance.

div.head: Conclusion
div.p: In order to achieve a better dynamic performance, improved robustness and stability, a new time domain performance criterion was proposed in tuning process of the PID controller for the AVR system. The proposed objective function was used in the CS, PSO and ABC algorithms for optimum design of the PID controller parameters in the same AVR system. As can be seen from the simulation results obtained here, the proposed gain tuning method improved the system's dynamic response parameters such as maximum overshoot, rise time, settling time and steady

div.head: A C C E P T E D M
div.p: A N U S C R I P T state error. Moreover, the performance of the AVR with the proposed CS based PID controller was compared to the PID controllers tuned by different evolutionary algorithms with some performance evaluation criteria used in the recent literature. The comparative simulation results show that the proposed CS based PID approach was capable of obtaining a superior response performance as compared to the other optimized PID controllers with various objective functions. Furthermore, the performance of the proposed PID controller as well as the other optimized PID controllers was tested under dynamic parameter uncertainties of the AVR system. It is found that more robust stability and better dynamic performance characteristics were obtained by the proposed CS based PID controller compared with other PID controllers under the condition of the parameter uncertainty.

Concerning future studies, the proposed gain tuning method will be applied to tune the controllers such as fractional order PID (FOPID) controller, fuzzy PID and fuzzy FOPID controllers for more complex control systems.

div.head: Conflict of Interest Statement
div.p: We confirm that this article content has no conflicts of interest to declare.

div.p: A N U S C R I P T
